paragraphs.text:
%dep

/*
BEFORE START

if your are using Hortonworks Sandbox, make sure you added more cores and more memory to YARN
spark streaming requires at least 3 containers to run
*/

/* this step must be executed as first command, if you already executed other commands, please click in "Interpreter" and restart spark interpreter */

z.reset()
z.load("org.apache.spark:spark-streaming-twitter_2.10:1.4.1")
z.load("org.twitter4j:twitter4j-core:3.0.3")
z.load("org.twitter4j:twitter4j-media-support:3.0.3")
z.load("org.twitter4j:twitter4j-async:3.0.3")
z.load("org.twitter4j:twitter4j-examples:3.0.3")
z.load("org.twitter4j:twitter4j-stream:3.0.3")

%md

## Please make sure Linux OS has the ntpd daemon installed and running
...otherwise twitter connection will not work

result.msg:
Please make sure Linux OS has the ntpd daemon installed and running

…otherwise twitter connection will not work

paragraphs.text:
/*
UPDATE YOUR TWITTER CREDENTIALS -- DONE
*/


import org.apache.spark.streaming._
import org.apache.spark.streaming.twitter._
import org.apache.spark.storage.StorageLevel
import scala.io.Source
import scala.collection.mutable.HashMap
import java.io.File
import org.apache.log4j.Logger
import org.apache.log4j.Level
import sys.process.stringSeqToProcess
import twitter4j.HashtagEntity

/** Configures the Oauth Credentials for accessing Twitter */
def configureTwitterCredentials(apiKey: String, apiSecret: String, accessToken: String, accessTokenSecret: String) {
  val configs = new HashMap[String, String] ++= Seq(
    "apiKey" -> apiKey, "apiSecret" -> apiSecret, "accessToken" -> accessToken, "accessTokenSecret" -> accessTokenSecret)
  println("Configuring Twitter OAuth")
  configs.foreach{ case(key, value) =>
    if (value.trim.isEmpty) {
      throw new Exception("Error setting authentication - value for " + key + " not set")
    }
    val fullKey = "twitter4j.oauth." + key.replace("api", "consumer")
    System.setProperty(fullKey, value.trim)
    println("\tProperty " + fullKey + " set as [" + value.trim + "]")
  }
  println()
}

// Configure Twitter credentials -
// Using Application "HWXSparkDemo" by  Paul Hargis

val apiKey = "CTN7IiLuPrDRq7J0aqCNYLZle"
val apiSecret = "2On87TWCyuZAY35Q5qSb1LbOdsFSoOOSgVFO4Fc7UbqbCBcGiL"
val accessToken = "41158026-8FbWkmwVoUPu0RUEkQawT1sTLnE064bJGqyQphq5a"
val accessTokenSecret = "mTm4ztLDn3LmvbbPOBsRtbwU4Wh6fVtCadick81xI4KFs" 

configureTwitterCredentials(apiKey, apiSecret, accessToken, accessTokenSecret)

defined class Tweet

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Wait about 60 seconds to let Streaming window to accumulate some tweets

After running ssc.start() above, every 2 seconds will be collected as a micro-batch. We have requested that 600 seconds (10 minutes) of data be retained by the underlying RDD.

Note: You can also come back and re-run the sql queries to get access to more data, until the entire 10 minutes is collected. As new tweets are collected, tweets older than 10 minutes will be dropped from the RDD.

result.msg:
Wait about 60 seconds to let Streaming window to accumulate some tweets

After running ssc.start() above, every 2 seconds will be collected as a micro-batch. We have requested that 600 seconds (10 minutes) of data be retained by the underlying RDD.

Note: You can also come back and re-run the sql queries to get access to more data, until the entire 10 minutes is collected. As new tweets are collected, tweets older than 10 minutes will be dropped from the RDD.

paragraphs.text:
%sql
-- checking window contents

select from_unixtime(createdAt), count(1) from tweets group by createdAt order by createdAt

%sql

--using SQL to mix window data, with scala function and python function

select from_unixtime(createdAt) as created, screenName, sentiment(text) as sentiment, wordcount(text) as wordcount, text  from tweets

paragraphs.text:
%sql

--ploting sentiment

select  sentiment(text) as sentiment, count(1) from tweets group by sentiment(text)

%sql

--show most common words for positive and negatives tweets

select word, sentiment, count(1) as cnt
from 
(
   select from_unixtime(createdAt) as created, screenName, sentiment(text) as sentiment, wordcount(text) as wordcount, text  from tweets
) sub1
lateral view explode(split(text, ' ')) t as word 
where sentiment <> 'neutral'
group by word, sentiment
--having count(1) > 1
order by cnt desc

paragraphs.text:
%sql

select minute, sentiment, count(1) as cnt from
(
   select substr(from_unixtime(createdAt), 0, 16) as minute, screenName, sentiment(text) as sentiment, wordcount(text) as wordcount, text  from tweets
) sub1
group by minute, sentiment
order by minute

name: Workshop: Twitter and Spark Streaming Demo
